video.title: Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines 2 | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Way back in 2004, when people thought things 
were bad because the president of the United

States was merely a bit of a thicko, 
there was a little game called Vampire:

The Masquerade – Bloodlines based on the Vampire: 
The Masquerade tabletop roleplay setting that has

provided many useful services to the world, most 
importantly giving DnD players someone they can

look down upon. Vampire Bloodlines had a combat 
system about as engaging as slapping a bowl of

custard and generally ran about as stably as a 
tightrope walker trying to conceal an erection,

but it garnered a cult following due to having 
some good writing, fun ideas, and filling the

niche of helping a certain kind of person realize 
their dream of being a brooding, superpowered

creature of the night that perhaps their mum will 
finally have to take seriously. As such, a sequel,

Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines 2 has been 
kicking around development hell for a while now,

and after 20 fucking years has finally flopped 
into the light like a partially evolved fish.

On the audible grunt scale, Bloodlines 
2 blew threw &quot;Ooh!&quot; years ago. It&#39;s

gone through &quot;Mmm!&quot; to &quot;Mmmn&quot; to &quot;eeeeurgh&quot; 
and has now landed quite solidly at &quot;ugh.&quot;

But let&#39;s try not to let my knowledge that 
this game has been passed around for years

like the family fart jar distract from the actual 
experience of playing it. After all, I remember

enjoying the desperately Frankensteined-together 
fan-patched version of Bloodlines 1 that I played,

and I could quickly tell that Bloodlines 2 
was going to be a much stabler experience,

having divested itself of the inventory system, 
and most of the RPG elements, and the having more

than one hub map to explore, and basically 
anything one could call a side quest. Hey,

it&#39;s called streamlining. Travel light; 
move fast. And then do bugger all once

you get there because you forgot to pack 
your wallet. In Bloodlines 2, we play an

Elder—that&#39;s a senior vampire who&#39;s been around 
for centuries—recently awoken from torpor—that&#39;s

a state of inanimation vampires enter when 
staked through the heart—to find themselves

in modern-day Seattle—that&#39;s a big city in the 
northwestern U.S. named after Chief Si&#39;ahl of

the 19th century Duwamish and Suquamish tribes—who 
must integrate with the modern vampire community,

learn their problems, find solutions, and 
generally wipe everyone&#39;s dried out old bumsies.

And we introduce ourselves as Phyre because 
we&#39;re one of those people who really get off

on having to spell our name for people writing 
it down. &quot;No, no, P-H-Y-R-E. With a Y. Yes, my

parents didn&#39;t want to be like everyone else who 
names their child after their favorite Electric

Six album.&quot; Bloodlines 2 is, much like its 
predecessor, a first-person action-stealth RPG,

although with more of a traversal focus leaning 
very slightly in a Dishonored-y direction,

and as I said, it all takes place across 
a single, not particularly large hub map,

implying that one could very easily avoid becoming 
prey for the Seattle vampire community just by

avoiding a group of very specific five or six 
blocks in the inner city, which is apparently the

only area where anything related to them happens. 
But let&#39;s not gloss over the hub city because

if one were to break down the main gameplay 
loop of Bloodlines 2, it would be as follows:

Trudge across snowy city. Talk to a cock. 
Trudge back across snowy city. Stealth murder

whatever group of dudes are annoying said cock. 
Trudge across snowy city again. Go to bed. Yeah,

this is the undead fantasy life I always dreamed 
of while practicing kissing my own wrist under

my Vampire Lestat poster. And every time 
you get to an important story mission,

the game goes, &quot;Careful! Doing this now 
may lock off currently active side quests!&quot;

And I&#39;m like, &quot;Bitch, what side quests? I can&#39;t 
find any!&quot; Besides the infinitely redoable ones

where you drink from a mortal with either 
strawberry, grape, or blue raspberry-flavored

blood, and those always play out the same way: 
inexplicably enrage them, lure them to an alley,

chomp. Inexplicably seduce them, lure them to an 
alley, chomp. Or less inexplicably frighten them,

chase them into an alley, chomp. And hope to 
god that that indistinct blob near the bins

isn&#39;t yet another random homeless person because 
if you chomp while other mortals are watching,

that&#39;s a Masquerade violation, buster. Chances 
are you&#39;ll only know you&#39;re being watched AFTER

you start chomping, of course; the interface 
only has an eye icon to show that anyone at all

is watching you, and that includes the person 
you&#39;re about to bite open like a stubborn bag

of Maltesers. Oh no, looks like I&#39;ve violated 
the Masquerade; what happens now, game? &quot;Oh,

you&#39;re in such trouble. Now you have to climb 
up onto a rooftop and sit with your chin on your

fist until the meter goes back down again.&quot; 
Huh. From the way you always go on about it,

I assumed it&#39;d be worse. You do have to 
grind up blood types, at least early on,

as this is the only RPG element: 
unlocking new combat vampire powers.

Phyre&#39;s super cool self-insert fan fiction 
protagonist status means they can use any clan&#39;s

powers, so you can acquire the power to nail dudes 
to the wall with a barrage of blood spikes to

replace your starting power to flick them lightly 
on the ear and then profusely apologize. Once you

get into the actual missions, combat begins 
as the usual creeping around, waiting for a

chance to wedgie people affair made notable by the 
utterly braindead AI of the enemies who all have

the object permanence of a baby chimp, so if you 
put a blanket over your head, they get confused,

forget you were there, and start walking around 
in circles in a corner. Although direct combat

does inevitably ensue because even the ghoul and 
Thin-blood gangs have big, chonky dudes walking

around that you can&#39;t instakill, which for me 
does rather make me wonder if our status as an

Elder vampire hasn&#39;t been somewhat oversold as 
these genetically inferior wastrels appear to

have more health and can pull at our guts like a 
toddler with a box of Kleenex given half a chance,

and meanwhile, our default attack looks like we&#39;re 
trying to declare a hair pull slap fight. We can

telekinetically pick up guns and empty their clips 
at people, yes, but first, we need to find them

lying amid all the other debris on the ground in 
the split second afforded by the chaos of a fight.

I ended up just waving my hand at any 
random garbage and hoping for the best,

which had mixed results. &quot;Aha, face now the wrath 
of, er, Mr. Discarded Chinese Food Carton.&quot; Expect

disappointment if you&#39;re coming into this as 
a Bloodlines 1 fan; it does function better,

but Bloodlines 2 isn&#39;t the least bit as 
ambitious and its world and characters feel so,

for want of a better word, lifeless in comparison. 
I liked those bits in the flashback chapters where

we play the Malkavian detective dude as he 
has conversations with inanimate objects

to find clues, but that was mainly for the 
silly voices he put on, so at this point,

we&#39;re batting at the same level as The Muppet 
Show. Oh, and I enjoyed the traversal powers.

Vampire sprinting across rooftops and leaping 
across broad streets, gliding to the building

opposite presumably by flapping our ears very, 
very hard actually made me briefly feel like a

badass vampire dude—with very big ears—until the 
moment I land on the ground and wasn&#39;t allowed

to do it anymore lest I get Masquerade violations 
from the fun police. And in any case, the hub city

is too small and uninteresting to make the most 
of it. So, in conclusion... ooh, what would be

the best vampire joke to deploy at this point? 
Bloodlines 2: It Bites. Or maybe Bloodlines 2:

It&#39;s Nos Fer Everyone. Or how about Blah, I&#39;m 
Dracula. Don&#39;t Buy Bloodlines 2; It&#39;s Shit.
